title: ‘We’ll have a beer’: Steve Hansen and Eddie Jones swap texts before semi-final
text:
England and All Blacks head coaches have mutual respectWe are expanding our coverage of New Zealand. Please help us by supporting our independent journalism

The All Blacks head coach, Steve Hansen, has revealed his deep respect for England’s Eddie Jones after the duo swapped messages as their tactical dual approaches.

Almighty All Blacks lay waste to the side that inspired their rebuild | Liam Napier Read more

On Saturday night in Yokohama, when England and New Zealand collide in their first World Cup meeting since 1999, respect will be quickly set aside as a place in the final is furiously contested. But whatever transpires, the content of Hansen’s text exchange with Jones suggests tensions will be left there.

“I said: ‘Looking forward to seeing you and win, lose or draw we’ll have a beer afterwards,’” Hansen said as he parked New Zealand’s crushing 46-14 quarter-final victory over Ireland to focus on preparing for England.

At the start of this highly anticipated test week, Hansen was happy to detail why he held England’s head coach in such high regard.

“His passion, he loves the game. He’s got a work ethic second to none – he put himself in hospital when he was here, he worked that hard,” he said. “Anyone who loves the game will get my support. He’s done a fantastic job with England. They’ve got a world record for most wins in Test rugby along with ourselves. They’ve got a harder edge about them.

“Eddie has been part of a winning World Cup team with South Africa, he’s had the disappointment of losing to England when he was coaching Australia but to get to the final is being successful anyway, even if you don’t win it. He’s got to the ability to understand what’s coming and he’ll share those with his coaching and playing group.”

Facebook Twitter Pinterest Aaron Smith scored an early try in a dominant New Zealand win over Ireland in Saturday’s quarter-final. Photograph: Stu Forster/Getty Images

Hansen shares similar relationships with other coaches throughout the rugby world, formed during his 17-year career on the Test scene.

Last week, before the All Blacks crushed Ireland, Hansen caught up with the Ireland defence coach, Andy Farrell. Hansen previously enjoyed similar close ties with the former Springboks coach Heyneke Meyer, the pair often hosting midweek dinners when touring their respective nations.

Wales come from behind to beat 14-man France in World Cup quarter-final Read more

As the teams warmed up before Saturday’s quarter-final Hansen and the Ireland coach Joe Schmidt chatted animatedly in the middle of Tokyo Stadium for 10 minutes.

Hansen has, however, also fired plenty of verbal barbs in his time. The departing Australia coach Michael Cheika has been on the receiving end on several occasions. So, too, the Wales and British & Irish Lions coach Warren Gatland. Hansen claims these jibes are fun and games, part of the preliminary to the main theatre.

“You see some of the banter which is really only to help promote the game as being, ‘Oh these guys don’t like each other’, which couldn’t be further from the truth.

“Coaches, regardless of whether you’re playing against their team or not, go through the same emotions. You spend a lot of time in the same mental space. It’s a game of footy, it’s not life or death. The closer you are the more you communicate. It’s like when you play against your brother or your sister: it’s important, but it’s not life threatening.

“Rugby is a special game. Those of us that have been around long enough understand the game is bigger than everybody else. It’s the game that’s more important than all the coaches and players.

“One of the greatest things about the game is the camaraderie,” Hansen continued, “not only in your own team but that you get from being involved in a contest and sharing those moments and then moving on to the next one.

“The game has been professional for a wee while but if you look back in time, and this is where history is important, teams always shared those moments after Tests together. It’s something that is really important that we don’t lose.”

The All Blacks suffered one minor injury blow in their victory over Ireland with the openside flanker Matt Todd aggravating a troublesome shoulder complaint.

Hansen indicated Todd was unlikely to recover for England, which could pave the way for the larger physical presence of Shannon Frizell, the more traditional blindside option, to take a spot on the bench.
description: All Blacks head coach Steve Hansen has revealed his deep respect for England’s Eddie Jones after the duo swapped messages before next weekend’s Rugby World Cup semi-final
